#Text=CHAPTER X

#Text=Bibbs 's room , that neat apartment for transients to which the “ lamidal ” George had shown him upon his return , still bore the appearance of temporary quarters , possibly because Bibbs had no clear conception of himself as a permanent incumbent .

#Text=However , he had set upon the mantelpiece the two photographs that he owned : one , a “ group ” twenty years old -- his father and mother , with Jim and Roscoe as boys -- and the other a “ cabinet ” of Edith at sixteen .
#Text=And upon a table were the books he had taken from his trunk : Sartor Resartus , Virginibus Puerisque , Huckleberry Finn , and Afterwhiles .
#Text=There were some other books in the trunk -- a large one , which remained unremoved at the foot of the bed , adding to the general impression of transiency .

#Text=It contained nearly all the possessions as well as the secret life of Bibbs Sheridan , and Bibbs sat beside it , the day after his interview with his father , raking over a small collection of manuscripts in the top tray .
#Text=Some of these he glanced through dubiously , finding little comfort in them ; but one made him smile .
#Text=Then he shook his head ruefully indeed , and ruefully began to read it .
#Text=It was written on paper stamped “ Hood Sanitarium , ” and bore the title , “ Leisure . ”
#Text=A man may keep a quiet heart at seventy miles an hour , but not if he is running the train .
#Text=Nor is the habit of contemplation a useful quality in the stoker of a foundry furnace ; it will not be found to recommend him to the approbation of his superiors .
#Text=For a profession adapted solely to the pursuit of happiness in thinking , I would choose that of an invalid : his money is time and he may spend it on Olympus .
#Text=It will not suffice to be an amateur invalid .
#Text=To my way of thinking , the perfect practitioner must be to all outward purposes already dead if he is to begin the perfect enjoyment of life .
#Text=His serenity must not be disturbed by rumors of recovery ; he must lie serene in his long chair in the sunshine .
#Text=The world must be on the other side of the wall , and the wall must be so thick and so high that he cannot hear the roaring of the furnace fires and the screaming of the whistles .
#Text=Peace --
#Text=Having read so far as the word “ peace , ” Bibbs suffered an interruption interesting as a coincidence of contrast .

#Text=High voices sounded in the hall just outside his door ; and it became evident that a woman 's quarrel was in progress , the parties to it having begun it in Edith 's room , and continuing it vehemently as they came out into the hall .
#Text=“ Yes , you BETTER go home ! ” Bibbs heard his sister vociferating , shrilly .
#Text=“ You better go home and keep your mind a little more on your HUSBAND ! ”
#Text=“ Edie , Edie ! ” he heard his mother remonstrating , as peacemaker .
#Text=“ You see here ! ”
#Text=This was Sibyl , and her voice was both acrid and tremulous .
#Text=“ Do n't you talk to me that way ! I came here to tell Mother Sheridan what I 'd heard , and to let her tell Father Sheridan if she thought she ought to , and I did it for your own good . ”
#Text=“ Yes , you did ! ”
#Text=And Edith 's gibing laughter tooted loudly .
#Text=“ Yes , you did ! YOU did n't have any other reason ! OH no ! YOU do n't want to break it up between Bobby Lamhorn and me because -- ”
#Text=“ Edie , Edie !
#Text=Now , now ! ”

#Text=“ Oh , hush up , mamma ! I 'd like to know , then , if she says her new friends tell her he 's got such a reputation that he ought n't to come here , what about his not going to HER house . How -- ”
#Text=“ I 've explained that to Mother Sheridan . ”
#Text=Sibyl 's voice indicated that she was descending the stairs .
#Text=“ Married people are not the same .
#Text=Some things that should be shielded from a young girl -- ”
#Text=This seemed to have no very soothing effect upon Edith . “ '
#Text=Shielded from a young girl ' ! ” she shrilled .
#Text=“ You seem pretty willing to be the shield !
#Text=You look out Roscoe does n't notice what kind of a shield you are ! ”
#Text=Sibyl 's answer was inaudible , but Mrs. Sheridan 's flurried attempts at pacification were renewed .
#Text=“ Now , Edie , Edie , she means it for your good , and you 'd ought n't to -- ”
#Text=“ Oh , hush up , mamma , and let me alone !
#Text=If you dare tell papa -- ”
#Text=“ Now , now ! I 'm not going to tell him to-day , and maybe -- ”
#Text=“ You 've got to promise NEVER to tell him ! ” the girl cried , passionately .
#Text=“ Well , we 'll see .
#Text=You just come back in your own room , and we 'll -- ”
#Text=“ No ! I WON'T ' talk it over ' !

#Text=Stop pulling me ! Let me ALONE ! ” And Edith , flinging herself violently upon Bibbs 's door , jerked it open , swung round it into the room , slammed the door behind her , and threw herself , face down , upon the bed in such a riot of emotion that she had no perception of Bibbs 's presence in the room .
#Text=Gasping and sobbing in a passion of tears , she beat the coverlet and pillows with her clenched fists .
#Text=“ Sneak ! ” she babbled aloud .
#Text=“ Sneak ! Snake-in-the-grass ! Cat ! ”

#Text=Bibbs saw that she did not know he was there , and he went softly toward the door , hoping to get away before she became aware of him ; but some sound of his movement reached her , and she sat up , startled , facing him .
